  is a problem intended to be solved by users. Different with \<^prop>â€¹ğ—‰ğ—‹ğ–¾ğ—†ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¾ Qâ€º where
  boolean \<^prop>â€¹Qâ€º is a pure assertion being a verification condition,

  or a view shift or any others representing specific properties.

  In addition, \<^prop>â€¹â™aâ™râ™gâ™uâ™mâ™eâ™nâ™t Pâ€º suppresses any attempts from the automatic reasoner. \<^prop>â€¹Pâ€º
  will be protected as intact.

subsection â€¹Reasoning Obligationâ€º

definition Do  :: â€¹prop â‡’ propâ€º ("â™dâ™o _"   [3] 2) where [iff]: â€¹Do  X â‰¡ Xâ€º

text â€¹In a rule, \<^prop>â€¹â™dâ™o Aâ€º annotates the antecedent \<^prop>â€¹Aâ€º is a reasoning task as a result
obtained from the reasoning, instead of a prerequisite condition of applying the rule.
During the reasoning process,

â–ª once it encounters an antecedent \<^prop>â€¹Aâ€º not wrapped by â€¹â™dâ™oâ€º, \<^prop>â€¹Aâ€º is evaluated immediately
  and once it fails the search branch backtracks;

â–ª by contrast, once it encounters an antecedent \<^prop>â€¹â™dâ™o Aâ€º wrapped by â€¹â™dâ™oâ€º, it means an obtained
  reasoning obligation as an outcome of the reasoning,
  just like \<^prop>â€¹ğ—‰ğ—‹ğ–¾ğ—†ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¾ Pâ€º meaning an extracted verification condition.
  So conforming to \<^prop>â€¹ğ—‰ğ—‹ğ–¾ğ—†ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¾ Pâ€º, no immediate reasoning work is invoked and the antecedent
  is returned and is given before the \<^schematic_prop>â€¹ğ—ˆğ–»ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—€ğ–ºğ—ğ—‚ğ—ˆğ—‡ â€¦â€º in order,
  as an outcome of the reasoning,.

  For example, if during a reasoning process, two \<^prop>â€¹â™dâ™o A1â€º and \<^prop>â€¹â™dâ™o A2â€º are encountered in
  order, and if the reasoning succeeds, the final outcome would be
  \[ \<^schematic_prop>â€¹â™dâ™o A1 âŸ¹ â™dâ™o A2 âŸ¹ ğ—ˆğ–»ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—€ğ–ºğ—ğ—‚ğ—ˆğ—‡ â€¦ âŸ¹ Conclusionâ€º \]
â€º

subsection â€¹Text Labelâ€º

text â€¹This part presents a mechanism to encode text symbol inside sequent.
  It may be used anywhere needing some text annotation for any purpose.â€º

paragraph â€¹Label tagâ€º text â€¹embeds any text string in the name of a lambda abstraction from
  \<^typ>â€¹unitâ€º to \<^typ>â€¹unitâ€º, i.e. term â–©â€¹Abs ("embeded text", unit, Bound 0)â€º if readers are familiar with
  the internal representation of terms in Isabelle.

  This way encodes text strings using machine string which reaches the optimal performance.
  A deficiency is it is unstable for Î±-conversion. Fortunately, Î±-conversion doesn't happen during
  the unification with a schematic variable, although the unification with another label makes
  the result undecidable.
â€º

datatype label = LABEL_TAG "unit â‡’ unit"

lemma [cong]: "LABEL_TAG x â‰¡ LABEL_TAG x"  using reflexive .

lemma Ï†Programming_Method_All:

âŸ¹ PROP Ï†Programming_Method (Trueprop (All P)) M (â‹€x. PROP D x) (â‹€x. PROP R x) (â‹€x. PROP F x)â€º

lemma Ï†Programming_Method_ALL:
  â€¹ (â‹€x. PROP Ï†Programming_Method (P x) M (D x) (R x) (F x))
âŸ¹ PROP Ï†Programming_Method (â‹€x. PROP P x) M (â‹€x. PROP D x) (â‹€x. PROP R x) (â‹€x. PROP F x)â€º

Ï†reasoner_ML â€¹Ï†Programming_Method (Trueprop (All P))â€º 1000
  (â€¹PROP Ï†Programming_Method (Trueprop (All ?P)) _ _ _ _â€º)
  = â€¹fn (ctxt,sequent) =>
  let val _ $ (_ $ (_ $ P)) $ _ $ _ $ _ $ _ = Thm.major_prem_of sequent
      fun rename N' (Abs ("x",T,X)) = Abs (N',T,X)
        | rename N' (X $ Y) = rename N' X $ rename N' Y
        | rename _ X = X
      val rule = @{thm Ï†Programming_Method_All}
      val rule' = case P of Abs (N,_,_) => Thm.renamed_prop (rename N (Thm.prop_of rule)) rule
                          | _ => rule
  in Phi_Reasoner.single_RS rule' (ctxt,sequent)
  end
â€º

Ï†reasoner_ML â€¹Ï†Programming_Method (Pure.all P)â€º 1000
  (â€¹PROP Ï†Programming_Method (Pure.all ?P) _ _ _ _â€º)

subsection â€¹Ad-hoc Overloadâ€º

  Thm.declaration_attribute (fn th => fold (Phi_App_Rules.overload th) names))â€º

Ï†overloads cast â€¹Transform the content of a containerâ€º

text â€¹
Convention of Overloading Distance:

â–ª 0. Transparent, the matching is perfect.
â–ª 1. Almost Transparent, but still incomparable to the really transparent, meaning tiny cost still
      exists, maybe in time or reasoning only
â–ª 3. Expected Conversion: some conversion and therefore information lost is inevitable but it is
      expected so can be accepted.
â–ª 5. Less Expected Conversion: in some (rare) case the information lost can be severe
        but generally still can be accepted for most of usages.
â–ª 9. Slightly Aggressive.
â–ª 12. Aggressive in most of the situations.
â–ª 15. Bad.

Threshold Cost Always!
â€º

subsection â€¹Synthesisâ€º

text â€¹The synthesis involves not only making a program but also finding a view shift or a ToA.

On a ready state of a construction like â€¹ğ–¼ğ—ğ—‹ğ—‹ğ–¾ğ—‡ğ— blk [H] ğ—‹ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—ğ—…ğ—ğ—Œ ğ—‚ğ—‡ Sâ€º or â€¹(ğ–ºğ–»ğ—Œğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ–¼ğ—ğ—‚ğ—ˆğ—‡(x) ğ—‚ğ—Œ S)â€º,
the synthesis mechanism makes some program or find some ToA to bring or to make the given
specification come true. Example: given the specification â€¹Xâ€º, the synthesis mechanism is expected
to deduce â€¹ğ–¼ğ—ğ—‹ğ—‹ğ–¾ğ—‡ğ— blk [H] ğ—‹ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—ğ—…ğ—ğ—Œ ğ—‚ğ—‡ S'âŸ Xâ€º or â€¹(ğ–ºğ–»ğ—Œğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ–¼ğ—ğ—‚ğ—ˆğ—‡(x) ğ—‚ğ—Œ S'âŸ X)â€º. The state â€¹Sâ€º may be
changed to â€¹S'â€º, but the change is minimal and only necessary for synthesising the â€¹Xâ€º.

On a state sequent having some antecedent like â€¹P âŸ¹ Qâ€º, the synthesis mechanism is expected
to solve the antecedent â€¹Pâ€º according to the given specification from user.
For example, the â€¹Pâ€º can be the specification of a procedure to be programmed, like the guard
â€¹P â‰¡ ğ—‰ğ—‹ğ—ˆğ–¼ ?f â¦ƒ X âŸ¼ ?cond â¦‚ ğ—ğ–ºğ—… ğ”¹ â¦„â€º of the branch statement. In this case
the mechanism is to synthesis that guard according to the user-given specification, like â€¹$x > 2â€º
to synthesis â€¹ğ—‰ğ—‹ğ—ˆğ–¼ ?f â¦ƒ X âŸ¼ $x > 2 â¦‚ ğ—ğ–ºğ—… ğ”¹ â¦„â€º.
â€º

definition DoSynthesis :: â€¹'a â‡’ prop â‡’ prop â‡’ propâ€º
  where â€¹DoSynthesis term sequent result â‰¡ (PROP sequent âŸ¹ PROP result)â€º

lemma Ï†synthesis:
  â€¹ PROP sequent
âŸ¹ PROP DoSynthesis X sequent result
âŸ¹ PROP resultâ€º
  unfolding DoSynthesis_def .

text â€¹
  Overall, the synthesis procedure consists of 2 phases.
  The first phase is a pre-process parsing the user input. Performed by antecedent
    \<^schematic_prop>â€¹Synthesis_Parse input ?parsedâ€º,
  it rewrites the user \<^term>â€¹inputâ€º to \<^schematic_term>â€¹?parsedâ€º.

  The rewrite process enables user to input partially instead of always giving the complete
  assertion every time, for example, just the abstract object \<^term>â€¹xâ€º to
  denote \<^pattern_term>â€¹x â¦‚ _â€º and leave the type unspecified to accept anything.
  For example, user may input just an abstract object \<^term>â€¹xâ€º to mean to
    synthesis \<^term>â€¹x â¦‚ Tâ€º for some unspecified \<^term>â€¹Tâ€º;
    user may also input \<^term>â€¹0::natâ€º to mean to synthesis \<^term>â€¹0 â¦‚ Natural_Numberâ€º.

  One can disable Ï†_synthesis_parsing to disable this feature.

  The second phase does the real work, synthesising the â€¹?parsedâ€º.

  As the given specifications are on abstraction, ways to synthesis an abstract specification
  are many and not uniquely determined syntactically of course.
  Therefore we apply an A* algorithm according to explicitly annotated cost. The algorithm finds the
  solution having the minimum cost.

  Besides, in order to reduce the search space, we assume a large amount of operators having
  specific programs to refine them (such as plus and subtract),
  so that synthesising a composite expression can be split structurally (and syntactically) to
  several small problems for synthesising its operands and for finding a proper program refining the operator.

  To find such a proper instantiation requires to know the abstraction relations of the operands,
  but it is not an easy problem because transformation of abstraction can happen at every application.
  The choice of the abstraction relation of a sub-expression affects the synthesis of the inner
  operations of the sub-expression and also the outer operation using it.
  Choices of the intermediate abstraction relations have to be counted globally.

  Therefore the synthesis reasoning also contains two phases. The first phase split the synthesis
  problem for the original big composite expression down to several small problems of
  choosing the intermediate abstraction relations and instantiating proper refinement for each
  operators. And the second phase is an heuristic search finding the optimum choices
  and the instantiations.
  The first phase is a greedy algorithm as what we assumed.
  The first-reached solution (according to the PLPR priority of the configured rules) is adopted
  and the remains are dropped.
  The second phase is exhaustive for every possible search branches (with pruning).

  Candidates of the second phase are measured by the distance of the transformation used inside.
  An ideal solution is to involve no transformation at all.
  A transformation is an edge and each one is labelled with a distance manually.
  The distance of a path â€¹eâ‡©1;eâ‡©2;â€¦;eâ‡©nâ€º is the maximum distance of its edges (transformations),
  â€¹max{eâ‡©i}â€º.

â€º

  Only procedure rules need to be tagged by \<^const>â€¹synthesisâ€º. The view shift and the ToA do not.

    procedure or this transformation synthesises.

subsection â€¹Applicationâ€º
â€• â€¹of procedures, ToA, and any other thingsâ€º

text â€¹It is a generic framework allowing to apply general things on the state sequent.
These general things named âˆ—â€¹applicationâ€º includes
â–ª procedures --- therefore appending a procedure on the current construction
â–ª transformations of abstraction and view shifts --- transforming the abstract state
â–ª actions --- meta operations combining several applications or transformations, cf. section Action.

subsubsection â€¹Applying on Procedure Modeâ€º

text â€¹TODO: move this to user manual.

\begin{convention}
In an application, source \<^schematic_term>â€¹?Xâ€º denotes the pattern matching the whole state
and the frame rule is not used by which \<^schematic_term>â€¹?Xâ€º can actually match any leading items,
whereas source \<^schematic_term>â€¹?x â¦‚ ?Tâ€º matches only the first Ï†-type.
In this way, we differentiate the representation of the purpose for transforming the whole state
and that for only the single leading item.
\end{convention}

\begin{convention}
The construction in a ready state should always be specified by a simple MTF.
\end{convention}
â€º

subsubsection â€¹Applying on a Block / End a Blockâ€º

definition â€¹Simple_HO_Unification f f' âŸ· (f = f')â€º

text â€¹\<^schematic_prop>â€¹Simple_HO_Unification A (?f xâ‡©1 â€¦ xâ‡©n)â€º encodes a higher order unification
  which find an instantiation of â€¹fâ€º where terms â€¹xâ‡©1, â€¦, xâ‡©nâ€º are not free in â€¹fâ€º.

  Such â€¹fâ€º is the most general if â€¹xâ‡©1, â€¦, xâ‡©nâ€º are all variables.
  To prove this, we show there is a unique â€¹fâ€º such that â€¹f x â‰¡ Aâ€º if â€¹xâ€º is a variable
    not free in â€¹fâ€º.
  Assume â€¹fâ‡©1 x â‰¡ Aâ€º and â€¹fâ‡©2 x â‰¡ Aâ€º then we have â€¹fâ‡©1 x â‰¡ fâ‡©2 xâ€º
  and then â€¹(Î»x. fâ‡©1 x) â‰¡ (Î»x. fâ‡©2 x)â€º.
  Because x is not free in â€¹fâ‡©1, fâ‡©2â€º, by eta-contraction, we have â€¹fâ‡©1 â‰¡ fâ‡©2â€º.
  The â€¹â‰¡â€º here means alpha-beta-eta equivalence.
â€º

lemma Simple_HO_Unification_I:
  â€¹ Premise procedure_simplification (f = f')
âŸ¹ Simple_HO_Unification f f'â€º
  unfolding Simple_HO_Unification_def Premise_def by simp

Ï†reasoner_ML Simple_HO_Unification 1200 (â€¹Simple_HO_Unification ?f ?f'â€º) = â€¹
let

fun inc_bound 0 X = X
  | inc_bound d (Bound i) = Bound (i+d)
  | inc_bound d (A $ B) = inc_bound d A $ inc_bound d B
  | inc_bound d (Abs (N,T,X)) = Abs (N,T, inc_bound d X)
  | inc_bound _ X = X

fun abstract_bound_over (x, body) =
  let
    fun abs x lev tm =
      if x aconv tm then Bound lev
      else
        (case tm of
          Abs (a, T, t) => Abs (a, T, abs (inc_bound 1 x) (lev + 1) t)
        | t $ u =>
            (abs x lev t $ (abs x lev u handle Same.SAME => u)
              handle Same.SAME => t $ abs x lev u)
        | _ => raise Same.SAME)
  in abs x 0 body handle Same.SAME => body end

fun my_abstract_over _ (v as Free (name,ty)) body =
      Abs (name, ty, abstract_over (v,body))
  | my_abstract_over btys (Bound i) body =
      Abs ("", nth btys i, abstract_bound_over (Bound i,body))
  | my_abstract_over _ (v as Const (_,ty)) body =
      Abs ("", ty, abstract_over (v,body))
  | my_abstract_over _ v body =
      Abs ("", fastype_of v, abstract_bound_over (v,body))

fun dec_bound_level d [] = []
  | dec_bound_level d (h::l) = inc_bound (d+1) h :: (dec_bound_level (d+1) l)

in
  fn (ctxt,sequent) =>
    let
      val (Vs, _, \<^const>â€¹Truepropâ€º $ (Const (\<^const_name>â€¹Simple_HO_Unificationâ€º, _) $ f $ f'))
        = Phi_Help.leading_antecedent (Thm.prop_of sequent)
      val btys = rev (map snd Vs)
      val f' = Envir.beta_eta_contract f'
    in (case Term.strip_comb f' of (Var v, args) =>
        if forall is_Bound args
        then sequent
        else Thm.instantiate (TVars.empty, Vars.make [
                (v, Thm.cterm_of ctxt (fold_rev (my_abstract_over btys)
                                                (dec_bound_level (~ (length args)) args) f))])
             sequent
        | _ => sequent)
       |> (fn seq => Seq.single (ctxt, @{thm Simple_HO_Unification_I} RS seq))
    end
end

subsection â€¹Actionâ€º

text â€¹Action provides a kind of meta calling mechanism.
  The expression of an action is nothing but a syntactical symbol.
  The symbol itself does not given any semantic information about what it does exactly.
  Its effect to the programming is interpreted by reasoning, or more specifically, by the
    configured reasoning rules binding on the action symbol.
  The rules perform the actual transformations, applications, or any other operations.
  And this performance defines the semantics of the action.

  Applying an action can be read as invoking certain automatic operation linked to the name of the
  action, to do some transformations or generate some code or do anything feasible.
  It makes the action calling very flexible.
  Semantic conversion made by reasoners written in ML can be involved, which gives
  sufficient space for many automatic operation.
â€º

(*TODO: polish below*)

text â€¹The action symbol is encoded to be a fixed free variable or a constant of \<^typ>â€¹actionâ€º.
  Therefore the pattern matching can be native and fast.
  Note an action can be parameterized like, \<^typ>â€¹nat â‡’ bool â‡’ actionâ€º parameterized
    by a nat and a boolean. Other parameters can come from the sequent.
â€º

text â€¹\<^prop>â€¹A @action Actâ€º tells antecedent \<^prop>â€¹Aâ€º is bound to the action Act, typically
  a procedure rule or an implication or a view shift rule.â€º

definition Do_Action :: â€¹action â‡’ prop â‡’ prop â‡’ propâ€º
  where â€¹Do_Action action sequent result â‰¡ (PROP sequent âŸ¹ PROP result)â€º

text â€¹\<^prop>â€¹PROP Do_Action action sequent resultâ€º is the antecedent to be reasoned
  to return the construction result of the sequent by the action.â€º

declare [[Ï†reason_default_pattern â€¹PROP Do_Action ?A ?S _â€º â‡’ â€¹PROP Do_Action ?A ?S _â€º (100) ]]


subsubsection â€¹Two Methods of Applying Actionâ€º

text â€¹There are two way to activate the construction of an action.
  One is by application mechanism where user inputs a theorem of shape \<^prop>â€¹PROP Call_Action actionâ€º;
  another is by synthesis, where user inputs a cartouche of \<^term>â€¹actionâ€º.â€º

subsubsection â€¹Classes of Actionsâ€º

       The action has to always have the shape of `?remain_args âŸ ?the_first_arg âŸ¼ â‹¯`

Ï†processor pure_fact 2000 (â€¹PROP ?Pâ€º) â€¹
let
  val for_fixes = Scan.optional (Parse.$$$ "for" |-- Parse.!!! Parse.params) [];
  val statement = Parse.and_list1 (
          Parse_Spec.opt_thm_name ":" -- Scan.repeat1 Parse.prop -- for_fixes);
in
  fn (ctxt, sequent) => Parse.position \<^keyword>â€¹pure-factâ€º -- statement >> (
  fn ((_,pos), raw_statements) => fn _ =>
  let val id = Phi_ID.get ctxt

      (*We first generate names of the facts if not given*)
      fun gen_name (_, ids) = String.concatWith "_" ("Ï†fact" :: rev_map string_of_int [] ids)
      val ctxt' = fold_index (fn (i,(((b', raw_attrs),bodys'),fixes)) => fn ctxt =>
        let val id' = Phi_ID.cons i id
            fun id'' j = if fst id' = "" then NONE else SOME (Phi_ID.encode (Phi_ID.cons j id'))
            val attrs = map (Attrib.check_src ctxt #> Attrib.attribute_cmd ctxt) raw_attrs

            val b = if Binding.is_empty b'
                    then Binding.make (gen_name id', pos)
                    else b'
            val (_,ctxt') = Proof_Context.add_fixes_cmd fixes ctxt
            val thms = map (Syntax.parse_prop ctxt') bodys'
                     |> Syntax.check_props ctxt'
                     |> map_index (fn (j,term) => term
                          |> Thm.cterm_of ctxt'
                          |> Goal.init
                          |> (fn thm => Phi_Sledgehammer_Solver.auto (id'' j)
                                                    (ctxt', @{thm Premise_D[where mode=default]} RS thm))
                          |> Goal.conclude
                          |> single
                          |> Variable.export ctxt' ctxt
                          |> rpair []
                      )
          in snd (Proof_Context.note_thms "" ((b,attrs), thms) ctxt) end
    ) raw_statements ctxt

   in (ctxt', sequent)
  end
)
end
